case_vignette: A 22-year-old man comes to the physician because of headaches and blurry vision for the past 6 months. He also reports frequent episodes of vomiting over the last month. His father has died of renal cell carcinoma at the age of 37 years. Examination shows 20/40 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling and growth of capillary vessels in the temporal peripheral retina. An MRI of the brain shows an infratentorial mass. The patient undergoes surgical resection of the mass. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having headaches and blurry vision for the past 6 months, and I've been throwing up a lot over the last month.

Have you experienced any seizures or muscle weakness?

[The patient responds: "No, I haven't."]

Final Diagnosis: Migraine with vomiting and possible chronic migraine if symptoms persist for more than 3 months without a headache-free period. If symptoms worsen or new symptoms appear, please consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation.

trial_4.summarized_mcq: Based on the given symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is Craniopharyngioma. This condition is characterized by headaches, blurry vision, and vomiting, especially in the morning. Other neurological symptoms such as decreased level of consciousness, obesity, and growth failure may also be present. Craniopharyngioma is a non-cancerous (benign) tumor that arises from the pituitary gland or the stalk connecting it to the hypothalamus. Glioblastoma, Medulloblastoma, and Hemangioblastoma present with different symptoms.
